bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of original manuscript.

div1.p: I know a rich capitalist who, out of his wealth, built a marble church, the most splendid in the city; and when it was opened, he stood at the door, the first Sunday and helped the sexton show people to seats.— He was the meanest looking person in the place, and proud out of his building and wealth.

The Elementary Laws do not get excited and run and bawl to vindicate themselves.— Priests and The doctors might all deny the attraction of gravity, and that sublime law power would never complain.— Be thouyou like the grand powers.—

most certain sure—as reliable as Immortality—you the effects come whenappear after the causes appear.are born.
I see on the Egyptian head-rests the most hideous forms and combinations of groups as if they intended to scare away st
The genuine Man is not, as would have him, like one of a block of city houses, that can't stand except as it is upheld in the midst of the rests
Greater than b wires of iron or treaties, or even strong mutual interests is the Impathy.— When Creighton hove too to for many days and nights and rescued the wrecked thousand on the San Francisco
If a man spatter mud on his new clothes, by lifting a child or an old woman over the gslush let him nevertheless be content.— Mud like that strikes in and makes beauty spots

div1.head: Pride of birth.—
div1.p:
There is nothing in *
nothing royal blood, or the successioninheritance through a direct line of the name of the most historical heroes, or in any
tr *(the eminency of any office of President or Governor or Mayor,)
that begins to but that should make us carry our heads so high, and so fill us with more than imperial pride,bulging pride than ever spread itself in capitols, or courts, as the consciousness that we are hum human souls.— Office however high exalted, and wealth however capaciousmay but often show many a mean and starved nature

The best of such distinctions abstractly amounts to little.— Toiled for, suffered for, lived for, as they are by the vast majority of men, their only real charm is that they but faintly symbolize afar off the unspeakable haughtiness and nobilityleness which, are grace the soul personality of every man carries well, if he but once take the hint of his own inalienable birthright.

Love is the cause of causes.— N Out of the first Nothing and the—out of black fog of primevalof the nostrils Or original of VacuityDeath, that which hung ebbless and floodless vast and sluggish in the spread of space—it asked of God with undeniable will, something to satisfy itself us itself immortal longings.—.— From its By it then Chaos was staid with.— The Like A family Like a brood of beautiful children came from them whom we call the Laws of Nature.—
Yes he is like a small boy who raises a big kite, and it pulls entirely too hard for him.— He had better let it go ere it carry him entirely out up in the air and out of sight
A coffin swimming buoyantly on the swift flowing current of the river
Yes I believe in the Trinity—God Reality—God Beneficence or Love—and God Imortality or Growth.
He dives in the water for a deaddrowned man and sees the body and with open staring eyes and the hair floating out and up from his head

Out of the vast, first Nothing

Whom we call the laws of nature

div1.p: There are two attributes? of the soul, and both are illimitable and they are its north latitude and its south latitude.— One of these is Love.— The other is Dilation or Pride There so inconceivable haughty as the
The style of the most magnificent heroes or rulers is
Loyalty of some flatterer of royalty who (later) is brought to the scaffold

The reason that theWho do we turn look f back, as century after century adds to the length of the road between us,—why do we always turn with living pleasure and curiosity to the sayings and doings thirty centuries ago of wandering Jewish tribes, of Greek communities, of half savage Rome and Ethiopia and Persia? There is something in those sayings and doings that effuses direcly from the soul—Raw and bugling as they send it out, — They do notgive it fool send it out at second hand, but fresh and alive.—
* This Poetry, or aliment of the soul, we must have.— It is clamored for with the most irresistible longing.— Accordingly it is everywhere and upon each objec and all that our senses can
Children and simple people often touch the tune make speeches that illustrate this relationship with some of these relations better

Much TThe largest portion of what rides jauntily through the world literary worldavenue as poetry, and keeps the saddle for scores, perhaps fifties of years, is awkward and ill-bouncingbadlyill paced enough; Jinglingsuch as Love-songsshambles in long metre or short, some very some of them ardent, and but most of them very dismal and spavined, — make upboth styles having always been ready and numerous on the road,— and
*What stuff passes for poetry in the world
What awkward and ill-bouncing riders
What is printed in books or what not, and has rhymes attached to its tails, is but a very small portion of the poetry of
case of the driver who came in looking as natural as life, but was frozed dead and hard

A lawyer who had put off his case once, came in court and asked further delay, is a with tears in his eyes stating the death of his mother. The Judge was just granting his request, with great commiseration, when an old lady from the gallery cries out "O my son! how often have I whipped you for lying!"

All expr that makes clear this relation, and tracks defines the road between between any conceivable objects and the human spirit and explains what those objects mean, is poetry coarse or fine.— Even if the explanation be done at second and third hand numerous two or three removes and off, or as most are or distantly suggested, we are thankfulfolks take them and relish them; for we are greedy of this sort of feeding diet, and exceedingly voracious, never get weary tired of stuffing*
pork

Friends— I discover that among people whose company is pleasant to me I almost invariably grow fonder and fonder of those who without any who cordent constantly like me and are not afraid to show it steadily who and are good natured, and have no notably offensive ways, and don't blow hot and cold (They may be pla ugly in the face; simple or slack in mind, and of common po employment.—)* tr

You shall go in some rich man's house, where the long suite of parlors have has been attacked and taken possession of by artists, ornamenters, makers of carpeting, marble mantels, curtains, good soft seats, raw morocco binding for books—and marble mantels What can be unbought; for the place yet looks very beggarly. The worthy gentleman who has footed the bills, for all these has surely omitted forgotten something,— We remember that hour moment first of April at the post office, when the young man in the linen jacket botched with ink handed us out of through the window a
very rare envelope, promising great things, when and, we found nothing at all inside but a piece of blank paper.—

* It is this which is the source of all Poetry; for there is in all men an instinct of the truth. in all men There is a file We have a sawtoothed appetite which restlessly hankers for some satisfactory food out of this immense and varied earth, beyond men something more satisfactory than
where the Congress meets is the sacred? place.— If they adjourn from there to some log house or shed of hemlock boards
